Description: Study for St Joseph, made for the first version of the painting 'The Triumph of the Innocents' (Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool; Bronkhurst no. 126)); whole-length figure seen from behind, running to right, head and shoulders turned and looking towards left, carrying a bag, and a wooden object from which a shoe hangs, across back, right hand supporting it, at left smaller study of same figure without his head and studies of hands. 1876 Silverpoint with graphite and scraping, on white prepared paper
Curator's comments: The study was made in Jerusalem. Hunt executed a number of later versions. Literature: Stacey Sell, 'The Interesting and Difficult Medium: The Silverpoint Revival in Nineteenth-century Britain', in Master Drawings 51 (2013), pp.63-86, esp. pp.68-70. Gere 1994 A study for the figure of St Joseph, carrying his carpenter's tools on his back and leading the donkey bearing the Virgin and the Infant Christ, in 'The Triumph of the Innocents' (Walker Art Gallery, Liverpool). The subject is essentially the 'Flight into Egypt', escorted by the souls of the Innocents massacred by King Herod. The painting was begun in Jerusalem, on Hunt's third visit to Palestine in 1875-8.
